issue.title: Picnic constant time tests fail
issue.body: It seems that #1116 has caused the constant time tests to fail, see https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/1822/workflows/698260d6-a9f1-4ecc-8586-e24e3368014b/jobs/15792.  @christianpaquin can you take a look?

comment.body: @baentsch, is it possible to run the weekly test on PR #1124?

issue.title: Adding multiple upstream support to doc generation
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR fixes an issue discovered by  Michael (https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1117#issuecomment-969116802).

This will update legacy yaml files so that the new format is followed, and when a yaml file is updated the script it indicate it has done so. When this happens I recommend double checking the yaml file to make sure the ordering "makes sense" to human eyes.

I also manually patched the yaml files of schemes that the copy_from_upstream.py script doesn't manage.

comment.body:
Hm, that's really odd. Did scripts/update_docs_from_yaml.py get updated when you pulled? The version in the PR doesn't have the line that is causing the error: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/aa4beb1b394e34c35f76ceac7456a790079a34e5/scripts/update_docs_from_yaml.py#L44

I just tried re-cloning my main branch and running the scripts from scratch and it works on my local machine.

issue.title: Adding multiple upstream support to doc generation
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR fixes an issue discovered by  Michael (https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1117#issuecomment-969116802).

This will update legacy yaml files so that the new format is followed, and when a yaml file is updated the script it indicate it has done so. When this happens I recommend double checking the yaml file to make sure the ordering "makes sense" to human eyes.

I also manually patched the yaml files of schemes that the copy_from_upstream.py script doesn't manage.

comment.body:
> Thanks for this update! The litmus test this passes is successful execution of `python3 copy_from_upstream.py copy`, right? There is one step missing though (and I wonder why we have not automated that): Running `python3 update_docs_from_yaml.py` to generate the .MD files: Those should be the files we read/check (treating the YML files only as intermediate/machine representations). 

I can add this no problem, I wasn't sure if there was a reason it was handled in to separate steps or not so I left it as is. :)


> Before merge, however, please amend the PR with the results of running that script too.

Would this cause an issue for git commits? I think there are a few schemes we have pulled in that are on a different commit than what the doc scripts will update to.

issue.title: Picnic constant time tests fail
issue.body: It seems that #1116 has caused the constant time tests to fail, see https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/1822/workflows/698260d6-a9f1-4ecc-8586-e24e3368014b/jobs/15792.  @christianpaquin can you take a look?

comment.body: I was able to repro the error on my machine with the right cmake config, and this PR fixes it locally; so it should be ok until the next weekly test.

issue.title: Adding multiple upstream support to doc generation
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR fixes an issue discovered by  Michael (https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1117#issuecomment-969116802).

This will update legacy yaml files so that the new format is followed, and when a yaml file is updated the script it indicate it has done so. When this happens I recommend double checking the yaml file to make sure the ordering "makes sense" to human eyes.

I also manually patched the yaml files of schemes that the copy_from_upstream.py script doesn't manage.

comment.body:
> I can add this no problem, I wasn't sure if there was a reason it was handled in to separate steps or not so I left it as is. :)

I don't know either :( Maybe @xvzcf might know (?)

> Would this cause an issue for git commits? I think there are a few schemes we have pulled in that are on a different commit than what the doc scripts will update to.

I was of the opinion that `copy_from_upstream.yml` is _the_ master file defining _all_ upstream (origins) without exception (beyond those algorithms that are manually added to `liboqs`) and that `update_docs_from_yaml.py` simply is converting all (machine-readable) YMLs to (human-readable) MDs (absolutely independently of algorithm provenance). Both should have no commit-dependency (or maybe I misunderstand the question).

issue.title: Adding multiple upstream support to doc generation
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR fixes an issue discovered by  Michael (https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1117#issuecomment-969116802).

This will update legacy yaml files so that the new format is followed, and when a yaml file is updated the script it indicate it has done so. When this happens I recommend double checking the yaml file to make sure the ordering "makes sense" to human eyes.

I also manually patched the yaml files of schemes that the copy_from_upstream.py script doesn't manage.

comment.body:
> I was of the opinion that `copy_from_upstream.yml` is _the_ master file defining _all_ upstream (origins) without exception (beyond those algorithms that are manually added to `liboqs`) and that `update_docs_from_yaml.py` simply is converting all (machine-readable) YMLs to (human-readable) MDs (absolutely independently of algorithm provenance). Both should have no commit-dependency (or maybe I misunderstand the question).

That is my understanding as well. The concern I have though is it looks like a few of our schemes aren't haven't been updated to the latest version of pqclean.

Example: Kyber is on commit faf5c3fe33e0b61c7c8a7888dd862bf5def17ad2 and hqc is on commit 5b8ef3baea3ffdfbf688a3a1bb8f02de44a67ec0.

If we run the script to update everything then the commits will be lost along the way and (some of) our updated docs will referencing the wrong commit.

issue.title: Adding multiple upstream support to doc generation
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR fixes an issue discovered by  Michael (https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1117#issuecomment-969116802).

This will update legacy yaml files so that the new format is followed, and when a yaml file is updated the script it indicate it has done so. When this happens I recommend double checking the yaml file to make sure the ordering "makes sense" to human eyes.

I also manually patched the yaml files of schemes that the copy_from_upstream.py script doesn't manage.

comment.body:
> I just tried re-cloning my main branch and running the scripts from scratch and it works on my local machine.

Sorry, I wasn't clear what I tried: I wanted to check that (only) the scripts are running OK on the current `liboqs` (main). I thus only copied over the files `copy_from_upstream.py`, `update_upstream_alg_docs.py` and `update_docs_from_yaml.py` (from martyrshot/updating-docs-for-multiple-upstreams) and then executed those in liboqs main, but to no avail:

```
$ python3 copy_from_upstream.py copy
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "copy_from_upstream.py", line 658, in <module>
    copy_from_upstream()
  File "copy_from_upstream.py", line 587, in copy_from_upstream
    update_upstream_alg_docs.do_it(os.environ['LIBOQS_DIR'])
  File "/home/mib/git/oqs/liboqs/scripts/copy_from_upstream/update_upstream_alg_docs.py", line 305, in do_it
    update_upstream_kem_alg_docs(liboqs_root, instructions['kems'], instructions['upstreams'], write_changes)
  File "/home/mib/git/oqs/liboqs/scripts/copy_from_upstream/update_upstream_alg_docs.py", line 117, in update_upstream_kem_alg_docs
    oqs_yaml['primary-upstream']['source'] = rhs_if_not_equal(oqs_yaml['primary-upstream']['source'], ("{}/commit/{}"+patches_done).format(upstream_base_url, ui['git_commit']), "primary-upstream")
KeyError: 'primary-upstream'
```

Now --not cutting corners any more-- I just cloned martyrshot/liboqs and moved to branch "updating-docs-for-multiple-upstreams" and ran these in their respective directories:
```
$ python3 copy_from_upstream.py copy
$ python3 update_docs_from_yaml.py
``` 
--> As you stated, no errors. So my corner-cutting (by just copying the scripts from your PR) was wrong. But what surprises me now is that git status is not empty at all (running these scripts should not result in anything new on this branch, right?) but rather:
```
$ git status
Auf Branch updating-docs-for-multiple-upstreams
Ihr Branch ist auf demselben Stand wie 'origin/updating-docs-for-multiple-upstreams'.

Änderungen, die nicht zum Commit vorgemerkt sind:
  (benutzen Sie "git add <Datei>...", um die Änderungen zum Commit vorzumerken)
  (benutzen Sie "git checkout -- <Datei>...", um die Änderungen im Arbeitsverzeichnis zu verwerfen)

	geändert:       docs/algorithms/kem/kyber.md
	geändert:       docs/algorithms/kem/kyber.yml
	geändert:       docs/algorithms/sig/falcon.md
	geändert:       docs/algorithms/sig/rainbow.md
	geändert:       docs/algorithms/sig/sphincs.md
	geändert:       src/kem/classic_mceliece/kem_classic_mceliece_348864.c
	geändert:       src/kem/classic_mceliece/kem_classic_mceliece_348864f.c
```

(Sorry for the German, but my Linux just feels "like it" :)

So: I can confirm your PR is OK -- but don't understand why it changes files when (re-)running the copy/doc-update commands.

issue.title: Adding multiple upstream support to doc generation
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR fixes an issue discovered by  Michael (https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1117#issuecomment-969116802).

This will update legacy yaml files so that the new format is followed, and when a yaml file is updated the script it indicate it has done so. When this happens I recommend double checking the yaml file to make sure the ordering "makes sense" to human eyes.

I also manually patched the yaml files of schemes that the copy_from_upstream.py script doesn't manage.

comment.body:
All of the src/* files will be copy from upstream using the new template format, which looks like it has an indenting issue. I've fixed that issue as part of this PR.

The docs/algorithms/sigs getting updated to the pqclean commit specified in copy_from_upstream.yml

The docs/algorithms/kems will be a combination of an updated pqclean commit and the new yaml and markdown format.

No worries about the german. Maybe more exposure to it will encourage me to start taking lessons again. :-)
